bibl.title: Letter from J. F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, January 25, 1946

div1.p: Siler discusses the pension that the Walter Reed Memorial Association provides for Emilie Lawrence Reed.

div1.head: Letter from J. F. Siler to Philip Showalter Hench, January 25, 1946
div1.opener:
THE PRESIDENT
GORGAS MEMORIAL INSTITUTE
OF
TROPICAL AND PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
INCORPORATED
1835 EYE STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
January 25, 1946
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Thank you so much for your note of December 29th. I must
apologize for the delay in acknowledging its receipt. It has been due
to the fact that I have been down with a very severe attack of contact
dermatitis. Thinking that this could probably be cured quickly by the
use of Penicillin ointment, I tried it out for two days. Unfortunately
it appears that I am one of those individuals whi react quite severely
to penicillin. After the two days my face looked like a combination of
erysipelas and mumps on both sides and I had to use wet boric compresses
on it for ten days. I am happy to say that it is getting back to normal
again and that in a few days it will be quite all right.

I am delighted that you had no difficulty in getting through
with your examination and that it was possible for you to reach home
before Christmas.

Needless to say we are delighted to have you a member of the
Walter Reed Memorial Association Board of Managers.

I have not been able to see General Reed recently but have
intended for some time to do so and discuss with him our ideas concerning
the eventual disposition of the funds of the Association. I feel quite
certain that it will be the desire of the members of the Board of Managers
to continue the income to Blossom after her mother's death with the under-
standing that after Blossom's death, permanent disposition will be made of
the fund. As you know, I brought the matter up feeling that while nothing
could be done about permanent disposition of the fund at the present time,
it would be well to secure the opinions of the present members of the Board
as a number of them are either close friends or acquaintances of Walter Reed
and might be able to give advice concerning disposition of the fund that
in their opinions would meet the wishes of Walter Reed, as they knew him.
With all good wishes for the year ahead, I am

closer.signed:
J. F. Siler
Col. U. S. Army, Retired
3434 - 34th Place, N.W.
Washington 16, D.C.
